abstracts.cdata!:
The project was satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. However, institutional development
            impact, was only modest, since inter-departmental
            coordination, particularly between central, and local
            governments, as well as with community groups is still weak,
            even though improvements are underway to strengthen
            community participation. Lessons address first, general
            issues for project implementation, such as the need to
            increase women participation in urban neighborhood
            management, to warrant a review in the provision of
            micro-credit within urban areas, and, to provide continuous
            assistance adjustments in urban management. Second, the use
            of funds to lease solid waste collection vehicles, is a
            practical way to increase private sector development, and
            should be evaluated. Similarly, acquisition of laboratory
            equipment, and personnel training in environmental
            protection, and pollution control should include civil
            society, and, drainage management should enforce guidelines
            to improve severe flooding. Third, specific Bank lessons,
            suggest the need for a less prescriptive approach for
            community-based development projects, rather focused on
            implementing objectives, and deeper recognition between
            environment, and health. However, support to
            performance-oriented maintenance management systems, should
            not be supported, until completion of brief analyses on
            previous activities, to establish clear objectives for
            future activities.
